description: 140 is a challenging minimalistic platformer with abstract colorful graphics. Rhythmic awareness is required to overcome obstacles controlled by an energetic, yet melancholic electronic soundtrack.
minimum_requirements: 最低: OS: Windows XP プロセッサー: 1.5 Ghz メモリー: 1 GB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0c ストレージ: 100 MB 利用可能

reviews.review_text: 140 is a simple game, but it is a very lovely fresh game. the game is on the lines of a casual puzzle/platform game where you control a cube/triangle/circle and you just have to save all the colored balls around the levels, it has surprisingly good boss fights and great level design. Nothing was impossible and it was all enjoyable due to the soundtrack and visuals. In my personal recommendation, if you have $5 to spare on this game, you should probably buy it, if you don't have the 5 dollars, it's been on the humble bundle a few times and its not super popular, so you could probably pick it up from someone for very cheap, if not free from a friend. The best way to explain this game is fresh and relaxing. Which doesn't come very often in puzzle/platform games.   Only true regret: the game is very very short. would've been angry if it was $5, but I spent $1 on a bundle.    So now the standard game rating:

140 is more like a piece of abstract artwork than a game intended to be played and enjoyed. It's simple elegance pervades every corner of the experience, to the extent it almost manages to push gameplay entirely out of the picture. The basic shapes and purposeful use of contrasting colors invokes comparisons to Mondrian, with a calculated simplicity and conspicuousness that elevates the presentation from rudimentary to a captivating example of minimalism. Moved by the beat of a reserved yet distinctive audio track, the experience feels alive as you move through levels, perfectly in sync with each other as if performing an elaborate dance.  In this way, you are something of an outlier; awkwardly progressing through areas you ought not to be in. This creates an odd sort of disconnect between the gameplay and the atmosphere, as while both work wonderfully together to create a brilliant rhythm based platformer, their is just something  off  about all of it that left me somewhat unsatisfied over the whole affair. I enjoyed every second of the one hour experience, but I also feel no need to spend anymore time within the game.  140 is undeniably a very cool game, one which demands a closer dissection of its elements than you would assume at first glance, the core of which is incredibly tight and polished. It made me think and left me feeling smarter for overcoming its challenges, but as the small side project of a single developer it is, it shouldn't be expected to have the amount of content or range of mechanics to feel like a fully fleshed out concept. It's an experiment, one that succeeds at what it attempts while prompting you to dig deeper into its refined define, but that is all it is and expectations should be set accordingly before entering its psychedelic world.
This is a pretty solid game.

With a minimalist visual artstyle and gameplay mechanics, 140 is a rather enjoyable 2D platformer. The great audio track starts off simple and as you progress through the level it slowly builds up to a great new age/electronic tune. You use the audio to your advantage as the environment moves and changes with the beat. Its a very short game which is expected for its price point and there are only 6 levels, 3 of them being unique while the other 3 are just reversed versions of the first minus the checkpoints. Yep that's right if you die you start the level again!   ----<DON'T BUY THIS GAME IF>----  -You like awesome graphics -You want a long adventure -2D platforming isn't your forte  ----<DO BUY THIS GAME IF>----  -You are searching for something unique and quirky -Enjoy a bit of a challenge

I beat the game and was really pleased, only to find out that I still had half the game left to complete, sort of...  I hate frustration platformers, but the first half of this game nailed the right level of difficulty for me. It mixes a rhythm game with a platformer, where as it goes on you'll need to use the abstract but enjoyable electronic music in order to time your movements.  Visually it's extremely simple, but surprisingly appealing and even beautiful at times. Screenshots absolutely do not do it justice. I feel the slick animations in time with the music and sound effects, particularly in the boss encounters, raise the visuals above what you'd expect from such simple assets. Even the way the character morphs between shapes while jump and move is brilliant, even better than the squash and stretch animations of Thomas Was Alone.  Mechanically I felt the game did an excellent job at throwing new ideas at the player constantly, while giving concise organic lessons before throwing them into something more difficult. Each of the 3 bosses I fought had that small learning period as well. The checkpoints are frequent and I was rarely frustrated. It seems some players aren't even aware of the 'second half', as they only appear if you go through the main menu back into the game, and go just further to the right than you had to go the first time. These 3 extra levels seem to be identical to the original 3, but mirrored left to right, using different color combinations, with permadeath... I didn't realize it the first time I tried the first mirrored level, until I died and spawned back at the intro. I decided to give it another crack and I was able to complete it without dying on the next try. The level of stress shoots through the roof, as the whole level becomes as tense as the hardest sections of the game. I don't really enjoy that level of difficulty, specifically the concept of punishing failure with repetition, but in this case it's not really extra content, so it can be safely skipped if you're not up to it.  My playtime so far, beating 4 of the 6 levels was just shy of an hour, but I quickly fell in love with it's simplicity. It doesn't match the charm of Thomas Was Alone, or the unbelievable visuals of FEZ, but it's damn good for what it is. It runs flawlessly at 120FPS at 1080P, but it probably supports higher resolutions as well. I played with a keyboard rather than a controller because I honestly just started it to see it, but it hooked me and I ended up beating the whole thing in one go. Pricing is up to the buyer, but I'd say it's certainly worth the asking price on a moderate sale, or in one of the dozen bundles it's been in.

Let's start things off with a disclaimer. I didn't like Limbo in all honesty. It had some nice ideas and really couldn't be faulted from a design point of view but personally I found the whole thing a bit boring.   This, from the Limbo director however is right up my street. It is in many ways like a remix on the idea of Limbo in that you are a thing, it's a minimilistic platformer, and you have no real abilities to speak of as such, just moving and jumping, but I found it to be an immersive experience with good tunes which brilliantly play an integral part in the gameplay and not only good design but a new idea or mechanic in almost every little section.   Admittedly it shouldn't take you more than an hour or so to complete and there's no real replay value there other than the challenge of trying to go through the game without dying atall, but if you like brilliantly designed, short, challenging and immersive games then go for it. I had my experience, I enjoyed it, I recommend it.

140 is a deceptively simple-looking 2D platformer, where you play as a silently morphing geometric shape attempting to collect all the shiny things and dodge all the obstacles. Pretty standard platformer fare, although the little twist on this one is that everything moves to the beat. I enjoy myself a good rhythm game - here's lookin' at you Space Channel 5 - so it's a pet peeve of mine when a 'rhythm' title has nothing to show for it other than a few elements moving to a basic pulse. From the screenshots I assumed 140 would be a prime example of that, but was proven wrong almost as soon as I started the first level.  There is no screenshot in the world that can truly demonstrate how flawless the rhythmic aspects of this game are.  Everything  responds to the music both technically and visually, whether it's the way an object moves, how it changes aesthetically to 'describe' a sound, or how the background music morphs, builds and fires off as you plunge further forward. It also offers a whole lot of rhythmic complexity, so if you were expecting to breeze through by counting 1-2-3-4 then brace yourself - we're talking tied notes, dotted rhythms and syncopation with this one. Finally, I especially loved some of the fantastic audio-visual moments that this game offers up, which I won't spoil but can guarantee you'll love seeing if you happen to be musically minded.  Getting worried that I'm talking about music and rhythm a lot? I wouldn't worry too much. The game is still playable if you find it hard to clap in time; it just means that certain obstacles will feel much, much harder to get through as the answer almost always involves just listening. Thankfully, the default levels come with unlimited deaths and generous checkpointing, so as long as you aren't aiming for every achievement you'll be fine.  So, the final verdict? 140 is a solid testimony to the rhythm-crossover genre, and I would recommend it to anybody who enjoys a rhythm game. I'd also give it a try if you're just looking for something a little different to play, as I'm not sure I've ever seen a game like this before. However... the second I post this review I will be uninstalling the game and never playing it again. Funny considering I'm singing such high praises of it, right? Yeah, well - you know that little 'as long as you aren't aiming for every achievement' disclaimer I made in the previous paragraph?  I have every achievement. Never. Again.
very short but very stylistic and relaxing to play! not worth buying if it's over $1 but worth playing if you own it :)
Very nice, music driven indie game with great electronic soundtrack. 7/10  NOTE: There's no Save Game! Once you quit - next time you'll start from the beginning.
short and challenging, gg

i had second thoughts about this game when i got it, to be honest.. but im glad i got it! didnt think i'd enjoy it as much, and i especially enjoy the music.  this platformer deals with timing with the music! and it can be difficult. the visuals are also beautiful! and the boss fights are entertaining.  the only thing i dont like about this is that there's no menu or a 'continue' button or a pause button, so if u exit the game by long pressing the esc key(which i accidentally did out of curiosity if there was an in-game menu to pause it) it wont save any progress at all. which is a little depressing coz i hit it right before the boss battle and had to start the level all over again.  but i did find out that if u defeat a boss, it saves the progress of completing a level and, if you exit the game at the next level, then come back tomorrow or whenever, the next level is available.  all in all -1 for nonexistent menu or pause button. also for going through an entire level just to get to the boss.. 9/10

This game is 'short' You can beat the first mode in about an hour. Actually beating the second mode will take you a few days I'm sure(It's just the same thing but reverse, you can't die or you start over). I Really Really enjoy this game. It's simple yet satisfying. Plus the music is awesome. I think the only thing I was actually disapointed with was the final boss. It just felt thrown in I guess. But other than that no complaints!
A really trippy rymthic platformer where every element of the scenery moves in sync with the music. Loved this one, it makes for a really psychedelic experience.

Great game! I loved it! It's an unique mixture between a platform and a rythm game. It took me a couple hours to complete it (not the hardcore levels) and despite the minimalistic graphic it's something you should play. It's challenging, well designed, great music... Go for it! :)  + Level design + Great music, perfectly fit to the game + Fun  + Very good gaming experience  - Minimalistic graphic  - Too short  My vote: 8/10

I love the way this game is played!   You play as a small object that basically shape shifts, leaping from platform to platform and trying to avoid obsticles that get in your way, which all work with the beat of the music.  You have to reach the end of each stage and collect a small object to put in its correct place, which is pretty simple. Theres 3 levels that are very short indeed, but at the end of each you encounter a challenge known as a 'boss' which can be a little tricky to complete but eventually you will get there.  But dont think this game is so easy, once you finish your 3 levels, theres 3 more levels known as mirror levels, and thats when it gets hard, you have to do each level without dying, which is possible but if you have no patience you will get angry fast! lol  Overall an excellent idea of a game, controls are easy to use and no complaints on the resolution and graphics, perfermance is fine too. Should you buy it? yeh if its cheap why not, and if you want a challenge then go for it, its a good test of patience :)
140 basically stands for the minimal IQ score required to beat the game in normal mode.    Jk, IQ tests are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.    10/10. Strongly recommend.
A simple game with a great atmosphere. The way the environtment mimics the music is great, and adds a fun rhythm aspect to the usual platforming.

This game is definetly amazing. Though the game is short and is like a casual game I really enjoyed playing it. It could use a save feature instead of me resetting the game every now and then. The sound track on the game is really amazing and is something I would love to listen to while working. Overall this game gets 4/5
Really cool minimalist rhythm game. Short, got it in a bundle.
easy but fun Short gameplay nice soundtrack

Not particularly hard or unfair, all that 140 asks of you is a consistent performance at a pace of 140 beats per minute.  '140' is a minimalist platformer (up until the bosses) in which all of the challenges are set to music. It doesn't sound like anything special but its execution is excellent. Controlling the game is easy. Your low speed and high acceleration make every move easily predictable. Every challenge is layed out before you in a way that allows you to almost instantly know what to do to overcome it. There was never death that I felt was unfairly due except perhaps for the bosses. However, even those really were my fault. The feeling of unfairness just came from how overwhelmed I was by them on the first try.  Every motion in the game apart from yours is set to a steady rhythm. Obstacles move in time with the music and platforms appear on-beat. You are a geometric shape that changes as your state does. A circle while moving on the ground, a triangle while airborne and a square while standing still. Every level consists of simple, timed platforming during which you must, at regular intervals, collect a little pick-up (whose movement represents a mechanic you're about enable) and take it back to a specific point to progress. Each level culminates with a boss. All of which are slightly different but are all basically about avoiding obstacles thrown at you as opposed to the ones you jump at in the platforming sections.  The music is sort of recycled for use throughout the entire game. Specific elements of it are only heard when particular mechanics come in to play so it's not always entirely the same but it's definitely not a different song. Again, the exception to this is the bosses. They come whith their own musical flavours. Consistent with the rest of the game but separating them from the platforming sections and each other. This all works in the game's favour. The music feels a part of the game's design and it helps you play. It's also awesome music.  '140' is very short, consisting of only three levels each taking around 20 minutes on the first try. The game does offer replayability to you through a mirror mode in which there are no checkpoints. I can easily see only a minority (although not necessarily a small one) being drawn in by this since, once you've beaten the game, you've seen and conqured every challenge. What more is there to do? Well, this 'hard mode' poses its own challenge by asking you to remain consistent in your abilities for an entire level. Fail and you must start from the beginning. Even if you reach the boss.  Personally, I liked this. I seems a solid enough goal to aim for seeing as you know what's coming is simple timing and fairly easy platforming. Even the bosses aren't as fraustrating a second time. If the game hadn't set this challenge for me, I might not have decided to try it but since it did, I gladly took it on.  '140' is an enjoyable distraction. If you liked things like 'Thomas Was Alone', 'Element4l', or 'Limbo', you could probably get into this.

This game is short, but hard as hell. It's a puzzle platformer, where you mainly need to listen to the music in the background, since it gives off keys to what is about to happen next. The main levels themselves are maybe not that hard, but some boss fights are incredibly hard and confusing. If you like hard platformers, then definitely check it out.

A very short game, yet incredibly intriguing. For those unsure about its length, it has 3 different levels (each one has new mechanics, mind you) and each one ends in a boss. If you want to enjoy a musical game to a catchy beat that changes as you progress, than by all means, get this game.

This is one of the most simple games I've ever played. It's combination of 'screw you, we'll make this impossible' and 'hey, want to hear the next badass song in this soundtrack' and the touch of feeling that you know how easy this actually is makes this game one of the best ever. It has the simplicity of portal, but the difficulty of Super Meat Boy.

Great experience. I was able to run through this in about an hour. Perhaps more importantly, I enjoyed it so much, I wanted to play through the whole game in one sitting. The music and the way it's wrapped around the gameplay is supremely satisfying. Well worth a play.
Really cool minimalist rhythm game. Short, got it in a bundle.
This is one is is a good one.

Very Stressfull. I haven't been this stressed out over a game in a long time.  It was a short, but good expirience. It was well built, it had no bugs, and it had an excellent soundtrack.  7/10 might tear out my eyeballs again

I only recommend this game if you can get it for less than 3€.  This game is awesome, truly. It has a very progressive gameplay, orchestrated by an awesome soundtrack. There's a lot of good ideas, and I was really amazed everytime I came across a new game mechanic. BUT it lacks content, and you can finish it in regular mode in 1 hour (Only 3 levels, each one with a boss at the end). There's a mirror mode, which is kinda hard since all checkpoints are desactivated, but it's still the same levels you've already done.  So, it's a very intense but short game. If it's on sale, just get it. Otherwise, wait.
A short fun game, don't play it with your speakers off!
This game is a bargain - especially if you get it in the sale as I did. Short but brilliant game, requires some skill, time and patience to complete.
Fun. Short. If it's on sale and you like geometry-based platformers, get it.
One of my favorite games. Always nice to have a little bit of a challenge. Awesome music helps too.
This game is brilliant. Probably the first interesting musical game I've ever played.

It is a very short game at that, but the initial way the game plays out is gorgeous. Adding layers upon layers onto the music only makes it the more better, and the challenges, or bosses, have a very unique set to them. This game only contains 3 levels, however you can truely challenge yourself to go onto the other end of the dark world and do them hardcore featuring harder levels overall, and having only a single life.

140 is a very 'primitive' platformer, if not for the seemless implementation of the music into its level design. It's great to see such a concept used this well and while simple, and very short, it's almost perfect it what it does.  Beware, I beat the game in about 1 hour. After that, you'll have an added challenge which I'll try later, but it does not seem to add much to the game, except for the challenge. (More on that later)  The game has 3 level, each with a Boss Fight in the end. 3 levels may seem waay too few content, but it's not quite like that. Basically, you'll unlock parts of the levels as you progress. You can see it as 3 chapters, but every level is integrated in the same space, which is essential in this game!   As usual,  presentation ! 140 has a very minimalist art style, with psychadelic color schemes, and even some glitchy-ness to it. It's not your typical '2D retro pixelated graphics' that lots of game are using. Not at all. This game stands on its own, even regarding the art style.  It never gets too intrusive, presenting all the information you need very clearly. I really liked it! Besides, the background also pulses in sync with the music, so it adds to the whole 'atmosphere'.  It's hard to talk about its  music  without talking about the  gameplay  at once! All I can say for now is that I enjoyed the music for this game. It's pretty much electronic dance music, but there's more to it than that.  As I said before, it's a primitive platformer. Well, kind of.  All your character does is move to left and right, and jump. The jump time it also always the same, no wall jumping, no double jumping, no gliding, nothing of the sort. It's as simple as it gets. Well, how can you still make an unique game with that? Music!  Similarly to Beatbuddy, this game uses music to its full potential. Every obstacle in the game is coordinated with the beat of the music, which makes this game all about timing.  Another game you can take in mind is BitTrip Runner (and the BitTrip franchise in general) regarding how it does its music. You're given layers of the songs as you progress through the game. It starts off with a very simple beat. And it builds on it, introducing new layers with the new obstacles. And it works perfectly!  I've been interested in how music can be integrated into gameplay for a while, and this game is a really, really good example!   Another noteworthy aspect about 140, is the way it  teaches  you about every obstacle. It never throws something very complicated at you, before explaining what it does, exclusively through gameplay. And music, ofcourse! Sometimes, you'll hear a new melody in the background, and you'll immediately know that you have to look for something around you. And you'll usually be presented with a very simple obstacle, to give you a general idea of how it works. Only then, come the bigger challenges. I never found it frustrating at all. It was a bit too easy, maybe, due to the very forgiving checkpoints (which I don't exactly mind). But if you're fond of challenge due to the lack of those, do not fret!  After you beat the game, you'll unlock 3 new levels. These are the previous 3 levels, but mirrored, and without checkpoints.  Every big level, is made up of smaller levels. Each time you complete a smaller 'level', something else will start moving, and with it comes a new layer of music. And that's pretty much how the game works. You just keep going to new areas until you reach the Boss fight.  It is indeed very simple, but also very effective! The way you need to pay attention to the rhythm of the music to overcome challenges, the way even the background contributes to that, it all comes together and gets you very in tune with the game. It's surprisingly immersive, and has a very good flow!  Another thing I've found great, was the Boss fights! There are only 3, but they play really differently to one another. They're almost minigames, and reminded my of something like SuperHexagon. The surreal visuals, coupled with the music, and twitch gameplay... yeah. But it's good! And it's not actually like SuperHexagon, only those elements. They're also timing based, and they do a great job of teaching you on the fly, with each phase getting progressively more complicated. It really does follow the design of the rest of the game. They start out simple, presenting you how it works, and then they'll challenge you, all through the game, without any words.  One nice addition is also how they end the Boss Fights. After the crazy colors spinning around, and the hectic music from the bosses, it suddenly stops. You're back into the Hub world, where everything is silent and grey. It's a very well timed break to the flow of the game. Well done!  I could see it being frustrating if the Boss fights are also a necessity to beat the Mirrored levels, without checkpoints, but I can't hold the game responsible. Its main content is accessible to everyone, and the rest is there to people fond of the old-school approach, I'm totally OK with that!   All in all, despite its length (again, 1hour, maybe even less, if you rush through it), this work is very, very well done. From its presentation, to its level design, and how it merges music and gameplay... I can't see much to complain about.  I'm really surprised about it, great little game! If you're a bit skeptical of the 5€ it costs... Well, maybe wait for a sale. But seriously, get this game and try it out, if you're into rhythm games, or platformers. It's definitely worth your time.
It was great
pretty mediocre game, quit after 30 mins

This game........ If you like musicy things, and colours, and annoying platformers, this is for you! I started playing this and the music was really cool, so I wanted to hear more, and I continued. And failed. A lot. Then I quit.

Very brilliantly designed platformer with a nice visual style and great soundtrack that is completely intergrated into it's mentally stimuatling gameplay. The game relies on fast thinking and learning as well as a sense of rythm.  It can get quite challenging, but is very rewarding and fun.   Well worth checking out.

This is the rhythm platformer of... the ending to 2001: A Space Odyssey.  140: A Space Odyssey  or  The Impossible Game + Thomas Was Alone + Super Hexagon  In other words, it's pretty freaking amazing. You gotta align your jumps and movements to the beat and it's often quite challenging, but satisfying when you manage to get it done. It's really cool when they introduce new mechanics, which each produce their own sounds that align to the beat as well. Within each level, the music keeps layering and changing, and the color scheme keeps switching. Very well thought out progression in these levels. And the basic, flat geometry and simple color scheme, although barebones and minimalist, are quite beautiful to look at and see in motion. Even better with the euphoric music and how well they complement each other. It has very interesting boss fights too, unlike what I have seen in any other game. Because they match the unique stlye and mechanics of the game. It's all very abstract and minimalist, but that is exactly what is intended and it enhances the mechanics that much more. Everything is tightly and cleverly designed to match a simple vision. It's really simple, but often the most genius things are the most simple. And that is how I can go into all this detail over some squares, circles and triangles.  So 140 is a great audio and visual experience, and a fun and challenging platformer. It's pretty short though, being just 6 levels. But for the price and the experience, I'd say it's definitely worth checking out.

Imagine Daft Punk stepping out of the Tron Movie, and retro-laser-beam you into some old C64 computer. This game is two hours of that feeling.  I don't care much for platformer games, and the trendy overuse of dubstep in media tires me. But I love 140, which takes both these elements and combines them to a game that is more than just the sum of its parts.  140 is not just a game, it's a little piece of art. It is relaxing and challenging at the same time. The music is wonderful, and so greatly interwoven with the visuals and the environment.  If you like the Trailer video, you will love the game.  About the people who say the game is 45 minutes short: Yes, the 3 basic levels can be beat in under an hour. But playing them in reverse mode (achievements 4 - 6) definitely takes you much longer, because it's much harder.

This game is all about realizing patterns and make movement according to them. If you enjoy rhytmic games which are combined with fast reaction platforming, make sure to experience this game. Also there's an interesting point about '140'. This game has actually no extraordinary feature (I mean some outstanding feature) but the game is extraordinary itself and that's only because of one thing, the one great thing... level design. Level design of '140' is impressive and it reminds me that there are games out there which are worth playing only because of level design, game like 'VVVVVV', 'Knytt Stories' and '140' itself.

It's a lot more fun than you think. I usually don't play this kind of games, but this one was extremely fun. Sadly it only has 3 Levels and 3 Extra Levels. If this game had something like an editor-mode, I bet it would've been even more fun 10/10 would play again!
The simplistic elements compliment one another to cluster an amusing experience. Recommended!

Fun and interesting rhythm based platformer.  Pros: Solid gameplay. Cool, building music. Interesting layering of music and environment effects.  Cons: Bonus mirror stages have no checkpoints, creating big time/skill necessity for completionists. Short gameplay.  Recommend getting for less than full price, 5$ is a bit much for 1-2 hours of enjoyable gameplay and 2-8 hours of frustration.
Great platformer!

It's a nicely paced minimalistic rhythmic platformer teaching you to trust your ears, not your eyes. Everytime the game appears to become boring it throws another mechanic at you. The aesthetic might not everyone's can of worms and I'd advise you to stay away from it if the psychodelic color flickering might cause you any discomfort. You probably won't get much more than an hour of game-time out of this title unless you're hunting for hidden achievements. Which raises the question if the price-tag is warranted.

Great rhythm game.  140 is a platforming, rhythm game developed by Carlson Games.  There is no story in this game.  As mentioned earlier, gameplay is a mix of platforming and music. There are three chapters, with each chapter having different objectives. You control a object that can shape shift between a square, triangle or circle. The goal in each chapter is to keep moving forward, collecting items and activating switches and platforming along the way. As you progress through the chapter the music will change. Some of the platforming can be challenging and can take a while to get right. One complaint is that there are no save points during chapters (only inbetween chapters) so when you quit and resume your game, you have to start at the begining of the chapter you were on. There are a total of 3 chapters for campaign as well as 3 challenge chapters which will test your skills.  To be a successful rhythm game you have to have good music. Does this game have good music? Well, yes it does. Audio is electronic pop which is not iritating to listen to.  Graphics are presented in a 2D fashion. The textures aren't well detailed, however this isn't important in a rhythm game.  A good rhythm game.

The visuals!!! Also a great soundtrack. Really short puzzle platformer to music!  I wasn't sure how I would like this one but it pulled me in and it's only about an hour for 3 levels of gameplay. You think there are no bosses in this game?? Think again! Since the game is so short it constantly introduces new mechanics and new music. Nothing gets stale.  I enjoyed my short time with this. Worth it.          YouTube™ Video:  140 - The colors!!!

I like to think of this game as the bit version of Bioshock Infinite. Find the girl (sphere) to get to another world but the same, so that you can pass the challenges. I like the puzzles, I like the music. The only think that is keeping me from playing is the fact that I get motion sick while doing so. So that's a bummer.
this game makes me rage so HARD, and thats why i love it The beat is amazing and the game moves to it 9.5/10

Awesome game. The first three levels are easy but when you get to the mirror levels it gets difficult. The thind boss of mirror stage 3 was so hard it took over 100 tries to beat. I enjoyed it soo much.
Challenging and visually insane, your eyeballs will hate you but you'll be too invested in beathing this darn thing to care.

140 (I suspect the name comes from the BPM of the music) is a great attempt at making movement/visuals interact with music/sound. Not much attention is given to sound in games these days, but as this game proves, sound can be used as more than an atmosphere-setter; it can be a game element in itself that provides important information to the player. I also love the art style - simple shapes and colours... This game is a work of art.  The game requires that you become aware of rhythms and patterns to proceed past each obstacle. Some of the obstacles are challenging and the game encourages you to figure out the solutions by yourself - no helps or prompts. To compensate for this, there are plenty of checkpoints (perhaps too many?) in each level so that you aren't left frustrated after dying. I found the 'boss' challenges to be at a perfect level of difficulty. I definitely recommend this, although extra levels would be nice (I completed all difficulties after a couple of hours).  I hope to see more games like this (visuals interacting with sound/music) in the future. If you guys know of any, let me know in the comments below.

Don't expect this to be a game that will blow you away, but consider it more like a game that'll make you rage quite a lot.   The graphics of 140 are simple and minimalistic yet powerful. It's quite the experience to play this game with headphones on or surround sound speakers - atleast it was for me. The game itself consists of 3 levels with 3 additional Shadow levels which can be played after you've finished the regular 3 levels. While the normal 3 levels are filled with checkpoints, the Shadow levels aren't - they're hardcore. If you die, you're out.  140 is a game that heavily relies on its awesome soundtrack. The idea is simple - jump, float and move following the game's rythm. An original idea, that Jeppe Carlsen (Creator of Limbo as well) worked out in an amazing and unique way, because this is probably the one and only time that this idea will stay unique.   I really enjoyed playing this short but powerful game. While I only clocked 3 hours, it felt like way more, and not in a negative way. This game is a must buy for everyone.

Despite its length, I enjoyed every minute of it.

I got this game in an 'artsy' Humble Bundle but I didn't know anything about it until I played. I would describe 140 as a rythym platformer. It sounds simple but the cool part is the techno music playing on each level. The platforms and obstacles in each level move to the different beats in the music. It's tough but it's all just really pretty and cool. I definitely recommend it.

The boss fights are very difficult, (Yes there are boss fights in an abstract platformer.) but rewarding to complete. This is a short game, but well excuted. Challenging, but a low penalty for failure keeps you going. No mid-level saving, which is annoying, but otherwise an enjoyable little experience.
The last boss might be easier to defeat if you just closed your eyes and guessed. I cant believe i just completed it. Music is cool.
140 really requires you play on beat. Three worlds and three levels will take you about an hour to finish. It's intense but rewarding.

it's a very hard platformer. The music is very good and changes with your surroundings. Also the surroundings of the level change as you progress through it. You really have to listen well to solve some of the puzzles. The last puzzle is really frustrating because you have to anticipate what is happening with your 'character' by listening to the music. The game is very minimalistic and colorful, not much to distract you from the actual platforming.   I had a lot of fun figuring out the puzzles in this game. It takes about 1.5 hours to finish this game. After that there are some achievements to gain. So i'd say 5 euro's is a good price. Also it is on sale right now.

What a game! The sound, rhythm and beat all go in hand with your success in completing this game's first 3 stages. Some tunes set he mood for when you are completing a hard section or boss.   This game is worth your valuable time.

140 is a rhythm-based platformer that challenges you with increasingly difficult stunts as your geometric character progresses through the game. Each time you complete a segment you save at a checkmark, which makes it less painful when you fail over and over again. Some people may struggle with the timing or precise controls required to complete some of the challenges, but I wouldn't call any of them impossible.  Most objects on the screen, besides your character, are simple squares. It doesn't get much simpler than that, but somehow it works. The graphics are vibrant and trippy at times, moving and changing colors to match the electronic music. The music by the way is fantastic! As you complete chapters and other key parts of the game the music will shift to reward the player with some awesome sounds.  My only complaint is that the game took me less than 90 minutes to complete. When you complete the 3 main acts (which takes 1-2 hours),you unlock the same 3 acts, but in reverse and without checkpoints. This should provide me some extra play time, but I'm certain that I will get frustrated and give up without the checkpoint handicap. So for that reason, the game doesn't have much replay value and the campaign is short, so I would only recommend this game if you find it on sale for $1-2.

140 is a tough game to review. On one hand, the various challenges and gorgeous visuals all tied into the beat of each level is implemented perfectly, offering a blissful yet difficult platforming experience that will leave a nice impression. On the other, even with the 5 dollar price tag, paying that much is a stretch for the little content provided. Consisting of only 3 levels, each about 5-10 minutes in length, 140 is stretched out through its increasing difficulty and bosses, which can last multiple times longer than the levels themselves, even with generous checkpoints.  The game shines brightest in the platforming sections, implementing the mechanics I've mentioned before and having a smooth difficulty curve that is never unfair, as you always know when it's your mistake. The first two bosses as well are decently balanced and don't take long to adapt and beat, even after a few tries, but it is the third and final boss that felt more of an excercise of frustration than any sort of challenge.  There is a method to the third boss' madness, but you have to adapt to a lot of variables to beat this one, even after you finally wrap your head around the constantly changing mechanics after every checkpoint.   Beating this boss provides no payoff either, as there is no new content following, nor a nod to your accomplishment outside of the standard steam achievement. You do unlock mirrored versions of all three levels, which could be fun if they didn't turn off checkpoints. Getting all the way to a boss only to die and lose all your progress and gain elevated blood pressure is not my idea of fun. If you're excessively masochistic and want to have an awful day, go for those challenge levels, but otherwise 140 is a nice surprise that has some nice shining moments, even if it never lives up to its potential.

As much as I enjoy platformer games, I'm not try hard enough to beat each of the levels again with one life. It is an understatement if someone is able to say they've truely beaten this game. Awesome game, pretty short though (normal levels took me just over 30 minutes to complete, with not many restarts but I am studying for a music degree so people less ryhmically aware, it's a very good challenge! There's enough challenge here, even if you have good rhythm and timing). It is extremely minimalist, as someone mentioned similar to 'thomas was alone' but even more minimal I guess.  After the short normal version, there is then the mirror levels, which are pretty much the same as the normal version but the whole level is mirrored and it's permadeath, so if you die you return to level select. Tried the first level and died right near the end, so this will obviously take me a little more then 30 minutes. This is where I think most of the value will be and a lot more hours invested, especially on the last level...  I picked it up in a bundle, you could probably get it cheaper in a steam sale too, but I don't think you would get too disappointed with it for £4...
Love it.
It's an original and entertaining game but it's way too short and easy to complete. BTW the music is awesome.
At first i thought it was very boring plaformer just by looking at the screen shots But after playing it i found it a great and sometimes very challanging game.

Nice, short rhythm platformer with really minimal graphics. The mirror levels are incredibly challenging especially without save points but feel great to beat.   The music really makes it stand out among other platformers, and combined with the simple style and gameplay makes for a really satisfying experience.

140 is an entertaining platformer with a catchy beat. It's got a VERY forgiving autosave system with infinite lives, so you won't get overly frustrated if you happen to hit a spot where you get killed a lot. If you have any experience with platform gaming at all, you should breeze through the majority of the game, including most of the level bosses. I personally found the end boss a bit annoying since the pattern shifts were making my head implode, but it was still good fun. Worth a buy for the music in the game at the least. Since it's got a really short play time from start to end (30-60 minutes) even when you count failing on the end boss multiple times, I'd wait for a sale to grab it.

fun abstract puzzle patforming. Graphics are simple as a design choice, being somewhat reminiscent of the earlist of television games (but still a bit more advanced than the old 2600 could truly have offered). The games real hook is how the music ties in with the motion of the game elements and builds in complexity and depth as the player makes progress through the level. The main levels offer about 1.5-2.5 hours of play and then are presented in a mirror image challenge mode with no respawn checkpoints (any player death means starting the level completely over). I haven't had the patience to tackle that and would rather have seen more different levels. But considering the price of the game and the high quality of what is there, I definitely recommend it.

This is a short game, probably takes an hour to complete. Controller is recommended. A simple, abstract platformer where the platforms and obstacles shift based on the beat of music. The music is great. Cool concept over-all.
Beautifully made game. I just love the way the music and platforming come together in a symphony of gaming pleasure. Great work!

This is a great minimalist platformer for when you have a few minutes and want to chill out. The music is synchronized to the timing and you can really find a nice relaxing zen sensation with this game.

Everything moves and changes according to the music, and the game feels incomplete without it. You can finish the 'easy' mode of the game in about 2 hours, and then you're rewarded with the impossible mode which might take you days or weeks to master.

If you love platformers, rhythm games, electro, or anything inbetween, this game is a must have. Albeit short, 140 packs a great experience into 3 levels that, along with having great music and platforming, provide a fair challenge to the player. (i will admit, there could be a few more levels).  There is no beating around the bush, this game can get hard at some points (See boss battle 3) but the controls are like that of Super Meat Boy, they are fluent and nice, which allows the challenge.  The pixelated astetic adds a lot to the minimalistic design and feel of 140, which along with looking simply beautiful, means that the game is very easy to simply pick up and play. 140 status: Completed primary campaign yet to 100%  Oh I am so damn conflicted about this review! I really don't know which way to go with it.  Look, this is a flash game. It has gorgeous visuals and sounds but it is still a flash game. This is okay though. I am absolutely a million times behind small time indie developers getting a more minimalist yet heavily polished experience onto steam so they can make some money and start off, even if the whole experience feels like a flash game. An example of this done right is Antichamber. It has the most blindingly shiny polish ever and it has length to boot. 140 has....well it has the polish at least.  140 is a moderately challenging platform game. Sadly though it only has 3 very short levels and it can be completed within a lunch break. Now you may be thinking that this might be a Nintendo hard game that makes up for its short life span with complicated levels, and really the levels aren't that hard at all, in fact the game doesn't really start to show its teeth until the third and final boss fight, and that's only because I'm completely thick and it took me a while to get used to the switch of gravity. I expect with practice you could probably speed run this without glitching in 25 or so minutes.   That is not to say that this is bad, by no means at all is it bad. Were it a free flash game it would be up there in most peoples top 10s. My only real complaints is the hit box seems to be a little bit out.  You see this is a platformer with static areas that will kill you and push you back to the last check point. There are no enemies to speak of which makes the experience feel a little lonely, rather the environment reacts with the music in the background which means that you have to get into rhythm with the sound track in order to progress which makes a very nice experience. The graphics are very simple and programmer arty which is fine with me. I see this as a very clever way of doing your first steps if you know a little about code but don't have the resources to hire a team. However everything is incredibly blocky but its stylistic, I am kind of on the fence for graphics. The hit detection seems a little unfairly sided to the static too, resting against a wall that suddenly changes will kill you, its only a pixel but you should really give the player the benefit of the doubt in most cases.  When you finish the game you can play a hard mode version of it, sadly though all the stages just go from right to left instead and they removed the check points. Not really worth much but at least its there, might add another hour or 2 to the game if you want to get your moneys worth. I would also like to point out that this game runs fine on low graphics for me but was a bit slow on high with my native res. I personally could not tell the difference and as its just 2d squares coloured I don't really see how you could up or lower the graphics, my rigs a little old now but it might be something for you to look out for.  At time of writing the game is £4 on steam and when I give my rating and recommendation I have to take that into account. Now remember I like the fact that these smaller flash type games are getting on steam, they are good fun little games, but they need a little bit more than what this offers and in this case its length. As I say, were this a freebie on newgrounds it would probably be getting an 8 or a 9 but as it stands I can only really give it a 4.  Don't take that as it being crap though! This score is just relative to its price. Make sure that you do play it if its in a bundle and you own it. But unless you really really really love the music/minimalistic genre you might want to wait until its a steam sale for at least half price or you might feel disappointed.  Remember 4/10 just means its below average, it doesn't mean you can't have fun with it. You may feel differently and I would love to hear your reasonings. Feel free to comment :)

This is a minimalistic music based platformer that will test your ear just as much as it will test your jumping skills. The game is short and sweet as I was able to beat it in just under an hour and enjoyed myself the whole time.

Quite a beautiful platformer, visually and aurally. This is the first platformer I've played to completely follow through on the claim that it's rhythmic. Your movements and the movement of the world objects are perfectly in step with the music, and the music deepends and evolves as you progress through each stage of a world. When I saw the trailer I thought you had to switch between the different shapes (circle, triangle, square) but that's actually done automatically as you move, thankfully. The main game (3 'worlds') is short. Probably only take 1-2 hours to complete. But there's 3 mirror/shadow worlds that are much harder that aren't factored into the 1-2 hour completion stat. Overall, it's a wonderful little platformer. Was made by one of the Limbo guys btw.

This is easily the best musically driven game I have played in years. The music is excellent, no pointless attempts to make a game fit a track that is popular. It's all written for the game itself. The graphics are clean and crisp, well polished even. Everything is smooth and perfectly timed. The only thing I can fault this game on is that it's so short.  It's not even expensive. Just buy it and play it. You won't regret it.

I'd give this game a conditional recommendation. As others have mentioned, it has a certain novelty to it, with the combination of rhythm game and plaformer mechanics. The difficulty between level progression and boss fights can be rather severe, particularly on level 3, but it isn't insurmountable by any means. That said, the game is very short and light on content. If you can pick it up during a sale or bundle for a buck or two, you might want to pull the trigger, but there probably isn't enough here for most gamers to feel that they got their money's worth at full price.
Short and sweet. Great combination of platforming and music. Fair level of challenge too.

Intelligent, challenging audio-platformer that doesn't outstay it's welcome, introduces simple mechanics seamlessly then grinds you into the dirt with them. Great fun, elegant design, fresh and well executed.
Awesome! 3 Levels is not much. Could be longer. Fun. One should smoke pot and play this.
good, short game with great music. Play with headphones.
Great Game 10000/10
10/10 Screw the final Boss

Best musically-dynamic platformer I have ever played. Simplistic and seemless design, super intuitive and super challenging in some parts. The tunes will get you into trouble with your neighbours because all you'll want to do will be to crank the volume right up!

This is a visually striking and audibly active masterpiece. It is perfect in what it is trying to accomplish in being a rhythm based platformer that isn't trying to be artificially hard. Everything is in tune with the tempo of the music and if you follow it you will succeed. The hard levels are mirrors of the first levels without checkpoints and give a good challenge to those who like to torture themselves. Overall if you like music/art/ and platformers you will love 140.  10/10

I just played through the game in around 45 minutes. It's polished, innovative, clever and it leaves you feeling satisfied with the experience. It consists of three levels of rhythm based platforming that increase in difficulty with a 'boss' at the end of each level. This is what took me around 45 minutes to play and was very well paced. After you complete that half of the game you unlock a second half which is a modified version of the first half but with everything mirrored and with no checkpoints so you have to start from the beginning if you make a mistake. This hardcore mode is a nice addition for people who enjoy the game and want to perfect their own gameplay vs. this small but perfect game.
Amazing sound and gameplay interaction.
This game is freaking amazing! Short but intense. Never felt so connected to music in a game.
No idea why its fun, but holy wow it is.

I got this from a Humbe Bundle purchase and I actually had no idea what kind of game this even was. I wanted something else in the bundle and this just came with it. I loaded this game up, planning on playing it for a few minutes and writing a scathing review (pessimistic hooligan that I am), but um...yeah, this was a very short but very entertaining game. It certainly had a few frustrating parts that had me cursing at my monitor from time to time, but overall, an impressive little game. I finished it in one sitting, but if you can get it for like...2 bucks or something, it's nice. If you like electronic music that's fairly melodic for the most part, you'd probably enjoy the music in this game. What was really cool was how all the stuff in the world (except you) that moves around, moves to the beat of the music, and you can plan your moves based on that. I never expected to recommend a game I'd never heard of that looked so simple, but it's quite good. Granted, I don't know if I'd ever play it again, but for a really low price and the intention of playing it once, I'd say go for it.
A fun little platformer that has quite a bit of challenge to it, albeit a little bit short.
Surprisingly simple game with an excellent beat to it.
Incredible platform game, with a great sound experience! Definitly worth it
Got this game as part of a humble bundle pack and had no idea what it was. It turned out to be very creative and found myself delighted over and over again :)
Nice simple but artsy looking platformer centered around audio cues.

140 is a neat minimalistic platformer where the music is coupled with the platforming. Depending on if you hate your life and want to redo the game inverted without checkpoints you can get more than 2-3 hours out of it. If you are good at platforming it might take only 1 hour, sadly I'm not.
Great little indie game. Very short (20~ minutes) but amusing.

Quite short. Visually appealing with a mechanic that isn't quite unique, but is applied well throughout.   There are three levels and a mirrored version of each of these levels. I couldn't bring myself to finish the mirror levels since the game gets quite boring once you've figured out each puzzle.  Overall recommendation: Grab it on sale.
what is 140
Great game. I can't wait to see what Carlsen Games does next!

Great fun, it's nice to have a platformer requiring timing to sync with the music. The special levels between worlds were also fun and imaginative, my only complain is it's a little short, finished it in about an hour. Worth a play though!

140 is a very interesting game. It's pretty addicting until you've beaten it, but thankfully the game is pretty short. There are two modes, the first of which may take 1-3 hours, the second of which will likely take a couple days of play (if you die, you restart).  The 'bosses' are well done, though the final boss feels a bit rushed. The colors and art direction is phenonemal, really gets you into the game. Where 140 shines, though, is the impressively good soundtrack. The music is some top-notch EDM/Electronica stuff that really brings the game together. The art and sound work in unison to create the games experience (art style/colors change to the beat of the music, as music changes based on your 'modes' and such.  For a platformer though, there is one game mechanic that really must be paid attention to, and that's the controls. The controls on this game, despite being a pretty basic shape-based, music-infused, artistic indie platformer, are very tight and allow for all the needed effects whilst playing.  Really a pleasure of an indie platformer, definitely worth the small price tag.

By far one of the most striking games I have ever played. The visuals, sound and game mechanics are absolutely seamless - sound being a part of the game mechanics. This game is HARD, but oh so rewarding. It's not just artificial difficulty; it's the kind of difficulty that makes you step back and think just how cleverly that objective was designed. 10/10.
the soundtrack of this game is the lynchpin for a lot of the movement in the platformer. Didnt think i could enjoy being a moveable square this much :)
A really nice music & a trully interesting rythme based gameplay - definitely worth being bought in a bundle.

An experience. A wonderful experience. I've never come across a minimalist game quite like this. Thomas Was Alone does not compare. This is an audiovisual experience that will make you think differently. Or maybe it's just the fact that I'm playing this at 12 AM and I'm delirious.  It's wonderful. Go play it.

Complete waste of time, and boy is it good at it! Graphics are sweet and simple, the graphic EQ in the background for the in-game effects is a nice touch and surprisingly doesn't interfere with gaming. The audio is top notch and takes many cues from the in-game action or location. And the levels? The levels are a blend of twitch/puzzle.  Did I mention the bosses? Those are cool as hell.
A really nice music & a trully interesting rythme based gameplay - definitely worth being bought in a bundle.

It was just about the most entertaining 2.5 hours of my life. Minimalist style meets platforming and bullet hell mechanics with rhythm as your guide. It's an oldschool gamer's dream come true.  There were a few moments early on when concepts such as timing or hit boxes seemed a bit off, but it's not hard to learn the quirks of this game and carry that knowledge into the three mirror levels.  9.5/10 is a fair rating for a $5 game I intend to master at least 3 more times.
Great game. I can't wait to see what Carlsen Games does next!
amazing game ! Highly recommended!

This is a short abstract rhythm based platformer. You control a shape that can only move to either side or jump while the environment transforms in time with the minimal techno soundtrack. Care to guess the BPM?   The music is great. The gameplay is satisfying, but might be difficult if you're not used to rhythm games. For example, I'd count to myself while playing (1 2 3 4, 2 2 3 4) and note that a certain event only happens on the third beat of every other measure.  For what it is, it's great; however, there's not a lot there. I beat the main game within an hour. Worth picking up during a steam sale if the concept appeals to you.

2 words. Mind Blown. This game is so simple yet so damn complicated. All you need is arrow keys and a damn good mind. Brovo to you good sir/sirs or mam who made this. Brovo!  For you playing i will give you one hint. Listen to the music. it is your guide.

140 was a definitely a delightful surprise, and I really did get way more enjoyment out of it than I thought I would.  The coolest thing about this game is the way they integrate the music with the gameplay, it's as much an element of the game as any of the visual elements.   At any rate, it's a short, sweet, very well crafted game which is neither too expensive or too cheap. I rarely care about playing newer games twice, but this is one I definitely want to play again.  concept 8/10 music: 10/10 gameplay: 9/10  overall: 8.5/10

140 is a one-of-a-kind, awesome little game, to be completed in a single sitting - it's pretty short, so you might want to get it on sale (well worth $2-3). If you're wondering why it's called 140, it's because that's the BPM of the music in the game. Once you understand what's going on in each section, it is just the right amount of challenging to be stimulating, rather than just frustrating - major props for that. If you're rhythmically challenged, then you're gonna have a really hard time, though!
Sample reduced death have never been so catchy!
A very short platformer with good level design and rhythm-based elements that tie into the game's soundtrack.

- Fun gameplay with great soundtrack. - Simple graphics, but good animations. - Good level of difficulty. - Very short without replayability. Because of that, I would recommend to wait for a sale if you plan to buy it.
A simple game, but brilliantly polished, with a soundtrack I wish I could buy. It won't take you long, but it's more than worth the investment.

Had a blast with this one. The simplicity of the graphics work well because they are integrated with the main rhythm mechanics. The music was perfect for the gameplay and the beats got more complex and layered as the game progressed, offering both more of a challenge and better music. While it is really short I could easily imagine playing this one several more times. One of the best rhythm games I've played.

Jamming soundtrack! But it's also disapointingly short and kinda easy (all 3 levels are easy to memorize, so the mirror/perfect run mode is doable for anyone), although one advantage of the former problem is that it, at least, makes the price very accessible! So if you're a rhythm fanatic like me, don't bother waiting for sales : just go get it!
Beautifully made game. I just love the way the music and platforming come together in a symphony of gaming pleasure. Great work!
Quick, fun, tricky
It's hard to beat, but it's worth it.

This has been a joy to play, the developers are geniuses. It delivers a fun experience for all sorts of gamers. Thus, it deserves a special award of its own. 'The Best Shapes Game' Humorously, the game is subject to a variety of different formats with regard to shapes. Rectangles, squares, triangles, circles, you name it!

Worth every penny. Controls are snappy and responsive, visuals are quite good, sound track is utterly fantastic... and the whole thing fits together incredibly well. Just make sure you have some decent headphones/speakers, as being able to hear the bass as well as possible helps with your enjoyment.

140 is a rhythm-based platformer. Changes in the music indicate a change in the stage. This is a good concept but the gameplay is kind of slow -- unlike most platformers, pretty much every jump requires waiting for that perfect moment.   The soundtrack is pretty great but my main problems with the game are that it can be frustrating and tedious. With the music dictating changes in the stage, you have to wait for the right moment to jump. This makes the platforming feel very slow.   There are only three stages in this game. I got it in a HumbleBundle, so I'm ok with the short length of the game but had I bought it separately, I'd feel a little ripped off.  One interesting thing is that each stage has a boss fight. The first two bosses aren't too difficult but the third boss is extremely frustrating.   Overall, 140 is a good concept but it is more boring and frustrating than fun. I think BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a much better rhythm-based platformer.

140...as others have stated; is a platformer with obstacles that are in sync with rhythm.   Let me start off by saying that the soundtrack was amazing...at first. I was pleasantly surprised to find that there wasn't much variety to the soundtrack so it quickly fell off and became boring. Though, it did slightly change...you can still feel it being recycled.   The graphical choice was probably more so due to lazyness, lack of imagination, time restraints, or even budget. Either way, this kind of style has been done before. Despite the fact that graphics obviously don't make the game...the devs could at least tried to do something new with it. (I do like the equalizer, though. That was somewhat nifty.)  Gameplay is straight forward. However, it becomes almost tedious. Your timing has to be absolutely perfect otherwise, you're going to have to hear the annoying static sound along with a checkpoint set back. At least there's checkpoints...  Though, I do not mind pinpoint precision. Games like Super Meat Boy and Electronic Super Boy require such. But...they have more of a satisfaction to it once completing levels and a better soundtrack.   I do understand that soundtrack and graphical choice are matter of opinion. Nevertheless, I believe that only goes to an extent.   If you're interested in this game; I suggest waiting for a pricedrop. It is definitely not worth $5 with the amount of OTHER indie games you can get for that price. Or, you know...get Super Meat Boy or Electronic Super Joy. (Or...Super Hexagon if you're fond of seizures.)  With a scoring system of cheese without beef. It would get charred cheese stuck to the bottom of a pan.

This is a wonderful indie game made horrible by the lack of proper a save system. If you don't finish a level in a single sitting, or if you walk away after getting frustrater by a particular challenge, there's no way to pick up where you left off.

Really basic platforming mechanics, “minimalist” art style and simple music beats that I could make in less than a minute. This is your typical hipster trash platformer. The only real reason you should own this game is if it came in a humble/indie bundle or some equivalent thing that gives you the game indirectly. It is not worth $5; in fact, I would argue its literally worthless. This feels like something a college student would do as a school project. The actual playtime you get from this is about an hour, maybe less or more taking into account how good you are at its “boss fights”. No replay value, no real content to absorb, nothing. This game is as basic as it looks.

This is an exceptionally mediocre game. There is an interesting premise, sort of, in the sense that a lot of the more complicated platforming is alleviated by timing your movements with the music. That's pretty cool but the developers never really expand upon this idea. The game is essentially a couple good ideas without an substance. To make matters worse, this game is incredibly easy (despite developer's claims) and very short. I beat the game in about 40 minutes with no inclination to play again.  I would love to recommend this, I really would, but simply put it's a mediocre game with some great ideas that are never really executed beyond an extremely simplistic manner. Will you like the game? Maybe. You will, however, be wishing there was more substance than what you are getting.

After finishing this platforming game I decided to give a negative karma here.  Pros:  + Intro vid + Varied background is consonant with rhythmic music in different level + Stimulating experience with bosses, need to adapt the style   Cons:  - Mild musics among same kind of games - Can't get achievements, totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ - Too few levels - Second round doesn't have new astonishing features, only graphics mirrored - Not that fun game, only move left or right at proper time - Author doesn't care about any issues(common issue for most of indie games)  Wishes:  + More levels + Extra OST DLC(more levels before this) + Trading cards  Others:  Some other games can be more addictive since if you can't follow the rhythm you still can make up a good step in them, but you can only move left or right in 140, not too much fun.  In level 3 you don't even need to match the melody to jump on the blocks, that's disappointing, the feature of the game is gone.
Cool concept, but lost interest pretty quickly. I did enjoy the way it forced you to figure out the game as you went, but only played it a few times before I got tired of it.

Game itself is good, but the ♥♥♥♥ing default controls are so ridiculous. Who the ♥♥♥♥ uses the arrow keys instead of WASD? Is this an XBox port or why does the developer not know how PC games are configured? What the actual ♥♥♥♥... Also: be careful, this game doesn't even support Borderless Window or Volume adjustments. Nice. Really really appreciated.

I almost never take the time to write a review of a steam game, most steam games I'm simply pleased with but not blown away, occasionally I'll write a positive review of a steam game I absolutely love. However, I don't believe I've taken the time to write a negative review of any steam game before this, so take all that into consideration when reading this review.   DO NOT BUY THIS GAME  Forgive the caps lock but I had to be clear, this game is a very good example of what people mean when they call a game 'indie' as a pejorative. Is it lazy? Yep. Is it self congradulatory? Yep. Is it overpriced and exploitative in design such that it takes a lot of time to beat just because of bad game design choices? Yep.  Think what you will about 'miminalism' but time and time again the indie community has shown that they believe it to mean 'getting away with being lazy by calling it an artistic choice'. This game uses solid colors like crazy, they aren't 'beautifully rendered' solid colors, they are just solid colors. In every area of game design aside from the music (which is decent) this game cuts corners on production.   First of all the mechanics consist of little more than basic 'avoid hazards, time jumps'. The hazards are a lazy static design. Honestly, this game looks a whole lot like what a game would look like if you set out with the idea of 'making the game requiring the least amount of effort to make and charging the most money you could get away with'. And you might suggest this is cynical or baseless, but think of this: This game does not have an options screen. You can adjust window size before playing but once you are in, you are in. Why doesn't this game have an options screen? Pretty much every game in the past 20 years has had an options screen, but for some reason this game is 'above having an options screen'.   What nerve the developer must have to think so highly of this game. And now, for the coding, this game could be coded by most decent coders in a week or two. That's it! Compare that to a game like 'The Binding of Isaac' a game with so much more depth and variety that most programmers couldn't even code or imagine. And take note, both games cost the same amount. That's the biggest insult is the price point. This game has THREE LEVELS. That's it, and how does the developer pad out the game with 'additional content'? He adds THE SAME THREE LEVELS again but with the X axis inverted on the level.   'Mirror mode' is acknowledged as incredibly easy to do, it's one line of code most of the time, inverting a level can be done in under a minute, it is absurdly easy, that's why some games have it as a 'cheat code'. Here, the almighty genius of a developer thinks so much of his game that he thinks these 3 inverted levels without checkpoints constitute 'new levels'.   What really irks me though is that somehow some people seem to be buying into this game. Read the reviews, I can't wrap my head around it, are we really such sheep that this passes as a quality 5 dollar game? I can't imagine all those reviews are real, I don't want to believe I live in a world where so many people could be such suckers. This guy is selling the video game equivalent of snake oil and people are gobbling it up.   To everybody who loves this game, I have a suggestion: You can play games of superior quality like this online FOR FREE, google kongregate or newgrounds, or google some game jam like ludum dare where people make games in literally 3 days and the top 200 entries for any game jam will be better (and less lazy) than this game. AND they will be free. I know for a fact that this developer has made more than enough money scamming people with 'minimalist' game design. The least he could do if he was going to be a lazy game designer is make it pretty. LIMBO is a pretty unremarkable game gameplay-wise, but at least it looked like the art took more that 2 seconds to make.   By this point I'd estimate most people have tuned out this review because it's quite long, but I had to make it and I had to make it long because I feel that passionately. Most of the indie game design community are very kind and selfless people they want their audience to enjoy their game. Here is the most damning thing about this game, and I truly believe it:  I don't think the developer cares if you like their game, only if you buy it.   I truly believe that, I got this game on some hefty sale and I still feel like I was ripped off. There are so many games of this and better quality online for free, this game has no art production value, very little innovation, and ONLY 3 LEVELS. It's a platformer with no art assets and only 3 levels that costs 5 bucks. Do you think a developer so selfish as to try to peddle such a scam of a game deserves any of your money?   Please do not buy this game, if for no other reason than to teach developers that they should care about their audience and not take advantage of them. Keep the indie community a better place by supporting good developers and not giving money to lazy exploitative developers such as this one.
Totally not worth the money, got it in a Humble Bundle. So that's fine I guess.

Quite the enjoyable game, but it's just too short to really get into it. Enjoyable rythmn but not particularly hard either. I guess whether you buy this depends on how much value you place in five dollars.
Minimal puzzle game, lasts for few hours. You need to synchronize with the nice background music to be able to complete it. All in all, nothing special.
More frustating than fun, lack of gameplay, and music that gets repetitive in the 2 hour lifespan of the game.

Found it pretty hard. Not gonna bother with the mirror levels, as if you die it even once, you're back at the start. Boss battle sometimes kinda random, to make it harder. Do I recommend it? Well, with so many other games out there, only if you're bored and looking at spending a couple of hours doing something different.

The game's the very first rhythm platformer I play, never seen anything like this and I've got to say that platforming and rhythm games really go well hand in hand; the controls work well, the physics are ok, the minimalistic style and music mesh well together. The game however is really too short and basic for its own good (it ends when you're getting the hang of it), it doesn't wear its welcome but it doesn't offer enough of a challenge either. It goes from having a checkpoint every two or three deathly pits in the standard stages, to having no checkpoints at all and requesting you complete entire levels without failing in the reverse stages, unlocked after you finish the game. No way I'm doing it, it wouldn't be fun, it'd be masochistic, with no reward or gratification at the end.
